title: What Is Sea Moss (Irish Moss)?
author: Kristeen Cherney; PhD
description: This red algae functions as a thickener for foods, a nutritional supplement, and a skin-care ingredient. Here's what to know, including how to prepare sea moss gel and whether to use a sea moss capsule.
cleaned_text: If you've perused some of the latest [superfoods](/photogallery/superfoods.aspx) and weight loss supplement fads online, you may have come across a supplement called sea moss, sometimes referred to as Irish moss. "Irish moss is a superfood that has recently gained widespread popularity after glowing endorsements from celebrities like Kim Kardashian," says [Jessica Cho, MD](https://www.wellnessatcenturycity.com/provider/jessica-cho-md), the founder of [Wellness at Century City](https://www.wellnessatcenturycity.com/), her personal practice in Los Angeles. What Is Sea Moss? [Sea moss proved an important source of nutrition](https://www.everydayhealth.com/diet-nutrition/sea-moss-gummies/guide/)in Ireland during the Great Famine in the mid-19th century, and Irish immigrants later established seaweed farms in the United States. Following agar shortages during World War II, sea moss increased in popularity as a replacement food thickener and emulsifier. Today, some of those same properties have sea moss making an appearance in the aforementioned wellness products — and there might be some merit to the claims, though research is limited and sea moss may not be appropriate for everyone. Common Questions & Answers Sea Moss Nutrition Facts [Kristin Gillespie, RD](https://exercisewithstyle.com/meet-the-team/), who is based in Virginia Beach, Virginia. - Calories: 5 - Total fat: 0.02 grams (g) - Protein: 0.5mcg But sea moss really stands out for its iodine content, says [Robin Foroutan, RDN](https://nutritionbyrobin.com/about), a registered dietitian with [The Morrison Center](https://www.morrisonhealth.com/staff/robin-foroutan/) in New York City. In pregnancy and infancy, thyroid hormones support healthy development of the brain and bones. What Are the Possible Health Benefits of Sea Moss? "This particular type of sea algae has been used medicinally around the world for a long time," she says. "When a food has been around medicinally that long, there's usually some truth to it, even if we don't have the research to support it." - Antibacterial - Antiviral - Anti-tumor - Anti-thrombotic - Anticoagulant - Anti-hyperlipidemic - Immunomodulatory Below are some of the other proposed health benefits associated with sea moss that may warrant further studies in humans. Keep in mind that the data so far mostly comes from studies in animals, not people, and some of the purported perks are only theoretical and require further research to be confirmed. Improved Gut Health The studies that have focused on sea moss in particular primarily support the idea that the when consumed in supplement form, this algae may benefit gut health, says [Kristin Kirkpatrick, RDN](https://www.kristinkirkpatrick.com/meet-kristin/), who is with the Cleveland Clinic Wellness Institute based in Denver, Colorado. Sea moss contains prebiotic mucilage, a type of fiber that provides food with beneficial gut microbes, which may in turn promote gut health. Stronger Immunity [mucus](/mucus/)membranes in the respiratory and digestive tracts, Foroutan says. (Mucus membranes produce mucus, which helps trap and remove germs from the body.) Supported Weight Loss May Boost Heart Health Lower Likelihood of Developing Certain Cancers [ultrasound](/ultrasound/guide/)-assisted extraction of its compounds, which inhibited the growth of some human cancer cell lines in the lab. Researchers noted this may be due to its antioxidant compounds. Such anti-cancer properties may also be attributed to the carrageenan content in sea moss and may even be helpful when combined with chemotherapy treatments. But more human studies are needed to confirm the potential role of sea moss in [cancer prevention](/cancer/guide/cancer-risk-factors-prevention/)and treatment. Stronger Treatment Against HPV Infection [human papillomavirus](/hpv/guide/)(HPV) infections. While more studies are needed, researchers believe that carrageenan may complement other preventive HPV therapies, such as vaccines. Healthier Skin Sea moss also appears to be growing in popularity as an ingredient in natural skin care products, though research into this use is lacking. In addition to its nutrients and antioxidants, sea moss contains sulfur, which can help treat acne as well as fungal and [yeast infections](/yeast-infection/guide/) of the skin, a board-certified dermatologist with Schweiger Dermatology Group in Hackensack, New Jersey. [Amino acids](/amino-acids/guide/) in the moss, such as arginine, may also benefit the skin by promoting the replacement of dead skin cells, Dr. Lal says. Potential Side Effects of Sea Moss While those possible benefits may sound great and this ingredient is nutritionally attractive, sea moss also carries some health risks to be aware of. [digestive problems](/digestive-health/common-digestive-conditions-from-top-bottom/)such as [bloating](/digestive-health/is-bloating-cause-for-concern/)," says Gillespie. Additionally, some experts believe that sea moss, like other seaweed, may benefit [digestive health](/digestive-health-pictures/superfoods-that-help-digestion.aspx)due to its fiber and live bacteria content. More research on the potential link between sea moss and digestive issues is needed. A more established concern is that seaweed including sea moss may negatively affect thyroid health. "If taken excessively or in combination with iodine-containing food sources, it can lead to iodine toxicity," Gillespie explains. "Too much iodine can have a negative impact on thyroid function, so many endocrinologists recommend avoiding iodine supplementation completely unless medically indicated." Always ask your doctor before taking these supplements, especially if you're taking other herbs, supplements, or medications. Forms of Sea Moss - Capsules - Gummies - Powders - Gel - Whole dried sea moss (sold as red seaweed or red algae) You can buy sea moss capsules, gummies, and powders at supplement stores. As for whole red seaweed, certain health food stores and online vendors carry it. Meanwhile, you may find sea moss gel in a health foods store or even make sea moss gel at home from dried sea moss. Instructions for Making Sea Moss Gel at Home Following [instructions from GoodFoodBaddie](https://goodfoodbaddie.com/how-to-prepare-sea-moss/) is a good place to start if you want to DIY sea moss gel. You'll rinse and soak dried sea moss for at least 12 hours, before blending it with the soak water until you achieve the desired consistency. Store it in an airtight container in the refrigerator or freezer. From there, you can add it to soups, smoothies, and other recipes for a nutrient boost in a healthy, balanced diet. Sea Moss Capsule Dosage Should I Take a Sea Moss Supplement? "Honestly, these supplements shouldn't be needed if you are consuming a general healthy diet that is rich in a variety of food types." Says Gillespie. "This supplement is not without risks, so it is better to reap nutritional benefits from whole food sources instead." How to Add Dried Sea Moss and Sea Moss Gel to Your Diet Sea moss has a neutral flavor that easily blends into a variety of other foods, Foroutan says, though it will change the texture of these dishes, making them thicker. For an updated twist, try the [recipe for a Vegan Jamaican Irish Sea Moss Drink from The Urben Life](https://theurbenlife.com/2021/06/25/sea-moss-drink/), which blends sea moss gel with dairy-free milk and dates for sweetness, while cinnamon, nutmeg, and vanilla add a touch of spice. How to Use Sea Moss in Your Skin Care Routine [dandruff](/dandruff/guide/), rosacea, folliculitis, and even facial [psoriasis](/psoriasis/guide/), he adds (though current research into sea moss for these specific conditions is lacking). Sea moss gel also makes a great base for other fun, DIY skin care masks. [Six recipes from sustainability-focused blog Treehugger](https://www.treehugger.com/sea-moss-face-mask-5210733) combine sea moss gel with skin-loving ingredients like honey, charcoal, and [aloe vera](/diet-nutrition/diet/aloe-vera-benefits-risks-uses-more/) for 10 to 30 minute skin care treatments. Summary Sea moss has a long history of use for its purported nutritional benefits, prebiotic profile, and antioxidant content. Unfortunately, though, the available research is currently very limited on sea moss's specific health and medical uses. As a gel, it may help to thicken foods, add a boost of certain nutrients, and soothe the skin. Yet people living with certain thyroid conditions should be cautious of sea moss's high iodine content. Talk to your doctor before adding this seaweed to your diet and skin-care routine to discuss the potential risks and benefits for your specific health situation.
